sections.text: Meeting 3 (20 FEB) Focus Block
Below is a complete, revised 25minute runofshow for Meeting 3’s Values & Principles Focus Block, incorporating everything we built in this thread:
F1 six synthesized themes (read-only)
F2 printed + onscreen 12 AI Seed Drafts
Camera as capture device
AI as formatter / reviewer / suggester (not the decider)
F3 “AI prescore → human confirm/override”
F4 Merge + Cap to 8–12
F5 camera+AI tradeoff analysis
F6 consent-first ratification with “one cannot consent” handling
By minute 25, you will have:
8–12 merged principles in F4 (numbered and sponsorinitialed)
1 finalized tradeoff statement in F5 (plus one backup recorded)
Consent record in F6 (and any exception/smallest-change requests captured)
Cut list recorded (not lost)
Assign these before the focus block begins:
Keeps pace, frames decisions, prevents debate spirals
Chooses collision pair when needed to maintain timebox
Runs consent check and captures smallest-change requests
Takes photos at marked moments
Runs prompts and posts output into “AI Suggestions (not decisions)” area
Never moves cards; never “decides” placements
Keeps wall orderly
Ensures sponsor initials on Pass items
Ensures FR tags and “Revise to…” notes are attached where needed
Mirrors wall moves to Miro (can lag slightly—capture photos as backup)
Creates merged stickies in F4 as directed by merge leads
Calls “30 seconds” and “time” for each step
F1 themes poster (read-only)
F2 grid with 12 printed AI Seed Drafts (P1–P12)
Blank stickies + thick markers
Pass / Revise / Park zones clearly labeled
FR tags list visible (FR1–FR6)
Sponsor rule reminder: “No Pass without initials”
F1 themes filled
F2 AI seed cards visible (same layout as printed)
Pass / Revise / Park lanes
F4 Merge + Cap slots (1–12)
F5 Tradeoff Statement Builder
F6 Ratification area
A side panel labeled: AI Suggestions (not decisions)

heading_path: Ground Rules You Say Once (and enforce quietly)
sections.text: Humans move the cards.

heading_path: Ground Rules You Say Once (and enforce quietly)
sections.text: Every kept principle has a human sponsor (initials).

heading_path: Ground Rules You Say Once (and enforce quietly)
sections.text: AI can suggest and score; AI cannot decide.

heading_path: Ground Rules You Say Once (and enforce quietly)
sections.text: 20second rule: if it’s not resolvable in 20 seconds → Revise.

heading_path: Ground Rules You Say Once (and enforce quietly)
sections.text: No wordsmithing in F3/F4: minimal edits only.

heading_path: 0:00–0:04 — Launch + F1 orientation + “what a principle is”
sections.text: Project the F1–F6 strip in one view.

heading_path: 0:00–0:04 — Launch + F1 orientation + “what a principle is”
sections.text: Point to the physical wall and then to Miro.

heading_path: 0:00–0:04 — Launch + F1 orientation + “what a principle is”
sections.text: “We have 25 minutes to produce a draft set of 8–12 principles plus one tradeoff statement.We’ll use AI to accelerate—camera captures, AI formats/reviews/suggests—but the committee decides.Every principle that survives has a human sponsor.”

heading_path: 0:00–0:04 — Launch + F1 orientation + “what a principle is”
sections.text: “These six themes are read-only. Any missing theme that would change our principles?If it’s nice-to-have but doesn’t change principles, we keep moving.”

heading_path: 0:00–0:04 — Launch + F1 orientation + “what a principle is”
sections.text: “Principles are decision language, not implementation steps.Use: ‘FCCPS will…’ or ‘When X conflicts with Y, we default to… unless…’”
Send members to the wall. Wall Marshal distributes markers.
Members interact with printed AI seeds and add new stickies.
“Everyone to the wall.Step 1: Adopt two AI seeds you think are important—initial them as sponsor.Step 2: Write one new principle or a revision on a sticky and place it under the appropriate theme.”
“Initial your adopted seeds.”
“One sticky = one principle. Keep it one sentence.”
Take a clean photo of the F2 wall (all candidates visible).
AI prescore → Human confirm/override

heading_path: 0:07–0:08 — AI pre-score runs while you frame the rule
sections.text: Runs the F3 pre-score prompt (below) and posts output in AI Suggestions.

heading_path: 0:07–0:08 — AI pre-score runs while you frame the rule
sections.text: “We’re using AI as a checklist robot. It will suggest Pass/Revise/Park so we can move faster—we still decide.Rule: AI suggests; humans move.If you disagree, you may override—write ‘OVERRIDE’ on the card or circle it on the AI list.Use the 20second rule: if you can’t fix it fast, it goes to Revise.”

heading_path: 0:07–0:08 — AI pre-score runs while you frame the rule
sections.text: 0:08–0:11 — Sponsors confirm/override and physically move cards

heading_path: 0:07–0:08 — AI pre-score runs while you frame the rule
sections.text: Two waves to reduce congestion:

heading_path: 0:07–0:08 — AI pre-score runs while you frame the rule
sections.text: Wave A: Learning + Assessment + Teacher

heading_path: 0:07–0:08 — AI pre-score runs while you frame the rule
sections.text: Wave B: Governance + Equity + Safe Tooling

heading_path: 0:07–0:08 — AI pre-score runs while you frame the rule
sections.text: For each card they sponsored:

heading_path: 0:07–0:08 — AI pre-score runs while you frame the rule
sections.text: Confirm AI label → move to Pass / Revise / Park

heading_path: 0:07–0:08 — AI pre-score runs while you frame the rule
sections.text: Override → move where they believe it belongs; mark “OVERRIDE”

heading_path: 0:07–0:08 — AI pre-score runs while you frame the rule
sections.text: If Revise → attach a mini note: “Revise to…” + FR tag if applicable

heading_path: 0:07–0:08 — AI pre-score runs while you frame the rule
sections.text: FR1 too vague

heading_path: 0:07–0:08 — AI pre-score runs while you frame the rule
sections.text: FR2 implementation detail

heading_path: 0:07–0:08 — AI pre-score runs while you frame the rule
sections.text: FR3 not testable

heading_path: 0:07–0:08 — AI pre-score runs while you frame the rule
sections.text: FR4 conflicts with principle

heading_path: 0:07–0:08 — AI pre-score runs while you frame the rule
sections.text: FR5 actor unclear

heading_path: 0:07–0:08 — AI pre-score runs while you frame the rule
sections.text: FR6 needs tradeoff decision

heading_path: 0:11–0:12 — Optional “second read” on Revise pile (only if needed)
sections.text: Photo the Revise pile and request minimal edits only.

heading_path: 0:11–0:12 — Optional “second read” on Revise pile (only if needed)
sections.text: “AI will propose smallest edits for Revise items. Sponsors choose whether to adopt.”
“Any strong objections to a placement? Call the card and the move in one sentence.If disagreement persists, it stays in Revise. F3 is now locked.”
Mirrors final Pass/Revise/Park positioning (exact text can lag; photos are the backup).
cluster, merge, cap to 8–12, record cut list
“F4 is de-duplication and capping. We are not wordsmithing.We will cluster near-duplicates, choose the strongest one sentence, and fill 8–12 slots.”
Assign two merge leads on the spot (e.g., one instructional/assessment, one governance/privacy).
Everyone else helps cluster.
Cluster Pass items by intent (not theme label): learning, integrity, teacher practice, governance, equity, privacy/trust.
Pick a base card per cluster; stack near-duplicates behind it.
“Pick a base card for each cluster. Stack duplicates behind it. Don’t rewrite yet—just cluster.”
Photo the clustered Pass set.
Run merge prompt (below) and post suggested merged wordings + cut list candidates.
scribe fills slots 1–12
Miro Scribe creates the merged stickies and places them into F4 slots.
“Merge leads: choose the best wording per cluster. Keep it one sentence.Everything not selected goes to the cut list—recorded, not lost.”

“Do we cover the big areas: learning, integrity, teacher practice, governance, equity, privacy/trust?Now: where do these collide? Call collisions in two words—privacy vs learning, equity vs consistency, etc.”
You pick one collision for F5 (to protect time).
Camera+AI tradeoff analysis + human selection/edit
“Tradeoff = what we prioritize when good principles collide.Not splitting the difference—choosing a default and naming exceptions.”
“Collision we will address today: [X vs Y].”
(Example collision used in our simulation: Equity/Accessibility vs Consistency/Comparability.)
Photo/screenshot the merged F4 list + a sticky that states the collision pair.
Posts 3 tradeoff statement options as separate stickies in F5 (A/B/C).
“Quick vote: A, B, or C.”“Now: smallest edit that makes it something you can support publicly—one sentence.”
“Who will sponsor this tradeoff statement? Initial it.”
Facilitator script
“We lock the chosen statement and record the runner-up as backup. Moving to F6.”
Consent-first + smallest-change request handling
“Consent means you can live with it and support it publicly.If you cannot consent, you must propose the smallest change that gets you to consent.”
“Thumbs up if you consent to the package: the merged principles plus the tradeoff statement.Hand up if you cannot consent.”
“Thank you. What’s the smallest change that would move you to consent? One sentence.”
If fixable in 30 seconds → apply edit now
If not fixable → record exception in F6 and proceed
“We’re not reopening the full list—only deciding whether we can adopt this smallest change right now.”
AI Operator takes one final photo of the ratified set (for minutes).
Miro Scribe adds: “Ratified by consent (date)” + exceptions/resolutions.
“Consent recorded. Exceptions captured. Focus Block complete.”

heading_path: The 12 AI Seed Drafts (P1–P12) for F2 (as printed cards)
sections.text: Use these as your default seed set:

heading_path: The 12 AI Seed Drafts (P1–P12) for F2 (as printed cards)
sections.text: P1 Deep skills first — FCCPS will design learning that requires student reasoning and reflection, even when AI assistance is available.

heading_path: The 12 AI Seed Drafts (P1–P12) for F2 (as printed cards)
sections.text: P2 AI as coach — FCCPS will encourage AI use that supports learning processes, not replacement of student work products.

heading_path: The 12 AI Seed Drafts (P1–P12) for F2 (as printed cards)
sections.text: P3 Process evidence — FCCPS will use assessment designs that make student thinking visible for high-stakes work.

heading_path: The 12 AI Seed Drafts (P1–P12) for F2 (as printed cards)
sections.text: P4 No detector-only decisions — FCCPS will not base integrity determinations solely on AI detection tools or probability scores.

heading_path: The 12 AI Seed Drafts (P1–P12) for F2 (as printed cards)
sections.text: P5 Teacher judgment leads — FCCPS will treat AI as a support tool; educators remain accountable decision-makers for instruction and evaluation.

heading_path: The 12 AI Seed Drafts (P1–P12) for F2 (as printed cards)
sections.text: P6 Support before expectation — FCCPS will not expect staff adoption without aligned training, exemplars, and accessible guidance.

heading_path: The 12 AI Seed Drafts (P1–P12) for F2 (as printed cards)
sections.text: P7 Tiered permissioning — FCCPS will define AI uses permitted by default, uses requiring review, and uses prohibited due to risk.

heading_path: The 12 AI Seed Drafts (P1–P12) for F2 (as printed cards)
sections.text: P8 Evidence-driven updates — FCCPS will revise AI guidance on a defined cadence using evidence of impact and incidents—not anecdotes.

heading_path: The 12 AI Seed Drafts (P1–P12) for F2 (as printed cards)
sections.text: P9 Equity by design — FCCPS will ensure access to approved AI tools and supports does not depend on home resources.

heading_path: The 12 AI Seed Drafts (P1–P12) for F2 (as printed cards)
sections.text: P10 Human review for high-stakes — FCCPS will require human oversight for AI-influenced decisions affecting grades, supports, or accommodations.

heading_path: The 12 AI Seed Drafts (P1–P12) for F2 (as printed cards)
sections.text: P11 Data minimization — FCCPS will minimize student data shared with AI systems and use only tools with appropriate protections.

heading_path: The 12 AI Seed Drafts (P1–P12) for F2 (as printed cards)
sections.text: P12 Plain-language transparency — FCCPS will communicate approved uses, expectations, and data practices to students and families clearly.
End of F2: full candidate wall (seeds + write-ins)
Mid F3 (optional): Revise pile only
Mid F4: clustered Pass set
Start F5: merged F4 list + chosen collision pair
End F6: final ratified set

Extract each principle candidate from the photo.Apply Quality Filter C1–C5. Output one line per card: ID/title — Suggested PASS/REVISE/PARK — FR tags — Minimal edit (if REVISE).Keep edits one sentence and not implementation-specific.

heading_path: Prompt 2: Minimal edits for Revise pile (optional)
sections.text: For each REVISE item, propose the smallest one-sentence edit to meet C1–C5. Include FR codes addressed.

Cluster by shared intent and identify near-duplicates.Propose one merged “best wording” principle per cluster (one sentence).Output: merged set of 8–12, cut list with sources, and likely collision pairs.

Using the merged principles and collision pair [X vs Y], draft 3 tradeoff statements (<30 words) using:(1) prioritize A even when it costs B because C(2) default X unless exception(3) accept risk to achieve benefit, mitigated by guardrailKeep it decision-guiding, not implementation-specific.
If AI output is late: proceed human-first using the printed checklist; AI becomes the “second read” for Revise and Merge.
If camera/photo is unreadable: Miro Scribe types rough text for Pass/Revise items; AI operator runs prompts from typed list.
If debate erupts: “20second rule → Revise” and move on.
If you want, I can also format this into a one-page facilitator script and a one-page operator script (printable), so each role can run their part without scanning a long document.
